The applicants were , at the material time , serving members of the NORP armed forces . They claim that , following an investigation into their sexual orientation , they were each discharged from the armed forces pursuant to the policy against homosexuals in the armed forces on the dates listed in the attached Appendix .

The applicants submitted a claim to the employment tribunal ( “ the ET ” ) arguing that their dismissal , and the circumstances leading to it , breached LAW DATE ( “ the CARDINAL Act ” ) . As a result of ORG judgment PERSON ( ORG ) ( Appellant ) v. Advocate General for GPE ( Respondent ) ( GPE ) dated DATE , the ET struck out Mr PERSON 's case ( CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) and dismissed ( by consent ) the remaining applications on the dates listed in the attached Appendix .

On DATE ORG ended its policy of excluding homosexuals from the NORP armed forces following the delivery of judgments in NORP and PERSON v. GPE ( nos . CARDINAL and ORG , CARDINAL DATE ) and PERSON and PERSON v. GPE ( nos . ORG and CARDINAL , ORG CARDINAL-VI ) .

On DATE PERSON , who had also been dismissed from ORG in DATE on grounds of his homosexuality , applied to ORG for leave to take judicial review proceedings on the basis that ORG policy was “ irrational ” , that it was in breach of ORG CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the LAW and that it was contrary to ORG CARDINAL/CARDINAL/EEC on the implementation of the principle of equal treatment for men and women as regards access to employment , vocational training and promotion , and working conditions ( “ LAW ” ) .

On DATE ORG ( “ the ECJ ” ) decided that transsexuals were protected from discrimination arising from their gender reassignment under ORG law and , in particular , by LAW ( P. v. S. and ORG [ DATE ] I.R.L.R CARDINAL ) . On DATE Mr PERSON was granted leave by ORG . On DATE ORG referred to the ECJ pursuant to the then Article CARDINAL of LAW the question of the applicability of LAW to differences of treatment based on sexual orientation ( NORP v. Secretary of ORG , ex parte Perkins , DATE ) .

On DATE the ECJ found that the refusal of travel concessions to a worker living with a person of the same sex could not be regarded as discrimination based on sex prohibited by ORG CARDINAL/CARDINAL/EEC on the approximation of the laws of the Member GPE relating to the application of the principle of equal pay for men and women ( “ the Equal Pay Directive ” ) ( Grant v. ORG [ DATE ] I.C.R. CARDINAL ) . Consequently , on CARDINAL DATE the ECJ enquired of ORG in the PERSON case whether it wished to maintain the Article CARDINAL reference . After a hearing between the parties , ORG decided to withdraw the question from the ECJ ( NORP v. Secretary of ORG , ex parte Perkins , DATE ) . Leave to appeal was refused .
This Act gave effect in domestic law to LAW . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(a ) of LAW provides :
“ A person discriminates against a woman in any circumstances relevant for the purposes of any provision of this LAW if -
( a ) on the ground of her sex he treats her less favourably than he treats or would treat a man . ”

Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) provides that section CARDINAL , and the provisions of Part II and III of the LAW relating to sex discrimination against women , are to be read as applying equally to the treatment of men , with the requisite modifications .
Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the LAW provides :

“ A comparison of the cases of persons of different sex ... under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ... must be such that the relevant circumstances in the CARDINAL case are the same , or not materially different , in the other . ”

Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) provides that it is unlawful for a person to discriminate against a female employee by dismissing her or subjecting her to any other detriment . If sexual harassment occurs in an employment context , it is considered “ detriment ” within the meaning of Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the LAW .
CARDINAL . ORG judgment on the DATE Act

On DATE ORG found in PERSON ( ORG ) ( Appellant ) v. Advocate General for GPE ( Respondent ) ( GPE ) that the word “ sex ” in LAW meant “ gender ” . It also found that the correct comparison was between the homosexual male applicant and a homosexual woman . These CARDINAL conclusions meant that the claim of sex discrimination and sexual harassment before it fell away : in both cases , the applicant would not have been treated any differently to a female homosexual .
